description.narrative: VET-Agriculture-SDC-phase 2 will provide support to further development and strengthening effective PPP and well-developed A-VET and extension systems that ensure improved delivery of relevant high quality Agriculture-VET (A-VET) and extension services

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative:
Outcome 1: A coherent coordination in VET and extension services is established and working Output 1.1. SSO (Agro Duo) has been formally registered by nine associations Final Version of the Feasibility Study on new coordination mechanism is developed
Output 1.2. 1.2.1/ 16 board meetings have been conducted during the reporting period. 1.2.2. One joint decision was accepted - the pilot results will be replicated additionally in two other regions of Georgia . 1.2.3. Not yet achieved 1.2.4. PPP models draft concept have been prepared and 6 PPP models have been developed and piloting process is starting in 3 regions 1.2.5/ 3 college representatives are participating and involved in the farmers consulting board meetings and 6 ideas were identified
Outcome 2: Public-private partnerships of A-VET and extension providers ensure delivery of relevant and high-quality services
Output 2.1. 2.1.1/ 20 new companies joined WBL scheme and are involved in the implementation process. 2.1.2/ Nine agri-professions represented by effective PPPs (including WBL program participants). Sub legal and legal acts developed during the reporting period: I. Regulation on authorization of educational institutions; II. New Authorization standard; III. General Education Integration – Rules and Procedures; IV. Regulation on obtaining the right of training/retraining program provision; V. Regulation on enrolment on training/retraining programs.
Output 2.2. 2.2.1/ 55 farmers board members have already been retrained in organizational design, institutional development and policy briefs preparation. 2.2.2/ Not yet achieved 2.2.3/ Through LOA project supports NCEQE secretariat for STT system functioning and status provision; 2.2.4; 2.2.5 and 2.2.6 not yet achieved
Output 2.3 2.3.1 Not yet achieved 2.3.2/ 29 extension officers from three regions of the country (Racha Leckhumi Kvemo Svaneti, Samegrelo Zemo Svaneti and Samtskhe Javakheti) training in institutional strengthening and strategic planning during the reporting period. 2.3.3/ 23 A-VET institutions and training providers are in the process of accreditation of long term and short term VET program; 2.3.4 Under the Regional Activities 3 partner colleges are involved in short-term training programmes implementation together with Regional and Municipal ICCs
Outcome 3: Male and female farmers and A-VET graduates learn and apply need-based agricultural knowledge and skills
Output 3.1. 3.1.1 and 3.1.2 Not yet achieved 3.1.3/ Six new WBL authorized programs represented by effective PPPs (Meat processing, aquaculture, gardening, fruit and vegetables processing, veterinary, vegetables production);
Output 3.2. 3.2.1/ 5,000 Farmers have been consulted and got information about the new technologies, information tools. practical recommendations. 3.2.2/ 3,042 persons used digital platform and 6,281 farmers have been reached through the SMS services. 3.2.2/ 18 RICC and ICCs got new hand tools and equipment worth of GEL 60,000 and use this equipment for extension.
Output 3.3. 3.3.1; 500 students graduated A-VET studies including (short term courses) in 2019. 3.3.2 15 new WBL students joined program in 2019.
3.3.3. Not yet achieved 3.3.4 Not yet achieved 3.3.5/ Two new STT packages in cheese production and winemaking are offered to the farmers 3.3.6 Not yet achieved

Outcome 1: A coherent coordination in VET and extension services is established and working
Output 1.1. Coordination mechanism for A-VET is strengthened with the stakeholders Output 1.1. Results 1.1.1/ 5 meetings organized 1.1.2/ 7 of joint decisions 1.1.3/ 1 documents prepared 1.1.4/ 7 public and private partnerships established 1.1.5/ 2 A-VET providers participating in farmers’ extension boards Output 1.2. Coordination mechanism for Extension is identified and piloted with the stakeholders 1.2.1/ 26 board meetings have been conducted during the reporting period (11 regional and 15 municipal level). 1.2.2. One joint decision was accepted - the pilot results will be replicated additionally in two other regions of Georgia. 1.2.3/1 joint decision made by the boards 1.2.4. PPP models draft concept have been prepared and 18 PPP models have been developed and piloted through the Regional Programs and College Support Grant Program 1.2.5/ 3 college representatives are participating and involved in the farmers consulting board meetings and 6 ideas were identified Outcome 2: Public-private partnerships of A-VET and extension providers ensure delivery of relevant and high-quality services Output 2.1. Public and private partners contribute to the provision of A-VET, including profile & curricula development, WBL implementation and examination 2.1.1/ 36 companies joined WBL scheme and is involved in the implementation process. 2.1.2/ 16 agri-professions represented by effective PPPs (including WBL program participants). In total 16 legal and sub-legal acts have been developed and approved by MoESCS. Most Important Ones are: 1) Regulation on authorization of educational institutions; 2) New Authorization standard; 3) General Education Integration – Rules and Procedures; 4) Regulation on obtaining the right of training/retraining program provision; 5) Regulation on enrolment on training/retraining programs. 6) Rules on obtaining the right of the work-based learning provider company in line with regulation on WBL and 7) Rules on the occupational standard development and approval. Output 2.2. Public and private partners are strengthened to contribute to the provision of farmer based extension services including short term training, counselling services, management advice, entrepreneurial support and other services. 2.2.1/ 17 farmer boards established and functioning (except of Guria that should be updated) PPPs’ new monitoring system in place and functional 2.2.2/ STT system is established and functional; Authorized short term training programs piloted by A-VET colleges. 2.2.3/ 2,720 additional GFA members (three categories) 2.2.4/ Amount of GFA’s non-donor funded income increase - 221,000GEL 2.2.5/ Yet to be performed in 2021 according to the project workplan - GFA accountability and transparency mechanism – 1 Financial audit in place 2.2.6 / 2 internal partnerships for VET and extension institutions established. 2.2.7 / 4 Colleges (including their branches) and training institutions obtained accreditation according to new regulations Output 2.3 A-VET Teachers and Extension Officers have the capacity to deliver relevant, quality A-VET and extension services. 2.3.1/ 3 in-service teachers and EO development activities. 8 subjects-based trainings developed and implemented for VET teachers as part of the Integrated 4th level programs implementation: 1. Communication in the Georgian Language; 2. Quantitative Literacy; 3. Entrepreneurship; 4. Citizenship; 5. Science (Physics); 6. Science (Chemistry); 7. Science (Geography); 8. Science (Biology). 2.3.2/ 52 extension officers and trainers from 47 municipalities of the country trained through the In-Service Training Program. 299 VET teachers trained in Integrated 4th level programs implementation by NEQEC 2.3.3/ 23 A-VET institutions and training providers are in the process of accreditation of long term and short-term VET program. 2.3.4/ Under the Regional Activities 3 partner colleges are involved in short-term training programmes implementation together with Regional and Municipal ICCs
Outcome 3: Male and female farmers and A-VET graduates learn and apply need-based agricultural knowledge and skills Output 3.1 (Self-) employment relevant measures including WBL are an integral part of A-VET provision. 3.1.1/ 9 modules with e-learning system is place 3.1.2/ To be accomplished in 2021 3.1.3/ 3 WBL authorized programs represented by effective PPPs (Fruit Growing, Milk Processing, Vegetable growing) in total 9 ((Meat processing, aquaculture, gardening, fruit and vegetables processing, veterinary, vegetables production); WBL authorized programs are in place; Output 3.2 High quality extension services and short-term trainings are offered to male and female farmers 3.2.1/ up to 5,000 farmers have been consulted and got information about the new technologies, information tools. practical recommendations. 3.2.2/ 24,723 farmers review different topics in Agropedia and /8,038 farmers have been reached through the SMS services. 3.2.2/ /18 RICC and ICCs got new hand tools and equipment worth of GEL 60,000 and use this equipment for extension.
Output 3.3 Agricultural professions and A-VET are attractive options including for women and youth 3.3.1/ 533 students graduated A-VET studies including (165 short-term courses) in 2020 (47% women). 3.3.2 / 39 new WBL students joined program in 2020 (in total 2019-2020 54). 3.3.3/ 5 students participated in international exchange program financed by the College Support Fund in 2020 3.3.5/ 9 new STT packages (horticulture, artificial cattle insemination, beekeeping, wine-processing, crafts distilling, Applied Farm Management, ’Ornamental garden care’, winemaking line technician, tea processing). 3.3.6/ 16 Agri professions offered by partner VET colleges

Outcome 1: A coherent coordination in A-VET and extension services is established and working
1.1/ 11 decisions made by private sector led sectorial council 1.2/6 of decisions implemented by the sectoral councils 1.3/11 proposals initiated by farmers led extension Boards 1.4 / 9 decisions considered by A-VET providers
Outcome 2: Public-private partnerships of A-VET and extension providers ensure delivery of relevant and high-quality services 2.1/ 24 PPP models are in the pilot stage in A-VET and AE. Results will be achieved for the end of 2021. 2.2/ 16,200 clients served by A-VET and AE delivery in total 2.3/ 21 operations Farmers Extension Boards are in place and they are functioning. Including 3 new extension boards in Guria region that has been recently added to the pilot scheme.
Outcome 3: Male and female farmers and A-VET graduates learn and apply need-based agricultural knowledge and skills 3.1/ 39 WBL graduates are in the system. 3.2/ up to 1500 students graduated in 2019-2021 A-VET professions including short-term training courses implemented through College Support Fund. 3.3/ 30 students 3.4/ 15,000 farmers have been consulted in total (5,000 in 2019 and 6,000 in 2020, 4,000 in 2021), and if consider 60% of adoption of the new technologies, figure will be up to 9,000 farmers
Output 1. Coordination mechanism for A-VET is strengthened with the stakeholders 1.1.1/ 7 meetings organized during the report period (in total 12) 1.1.2/ 7 of joint decisions 1.1.3/ 1 documents prepared 1.1.4/ 7 public and private partnerships established (in total 18) 1.1.5/ 4 A-VET providers participating in farmers’ extension boards
Output 1.2. Coordination mechanism for Extension is identified and piloted with the stakeholders 1.2.1/ 9 board meetings have been conducted during the reporting period (4 regional and 21 municipal level). 1.2.2./12 joint decision was accepted - the pilot results will be replicated additionally in two other regions of Georgia. 1.2.3/3 joint decision made by the boards 1.2.4. PPP models draft concept have been prepared and 24 PPP models have been developed and piloted through the Regional Programs and College Support Grant Program 1.2.5/ 4 college representatives are participating and involved in the farmers consulting board meetings and 6 ideas were identified (4 in total)
Output 2.1. Public and private partners contribute to the provision of A-VET, including profile & curricula development, WBL implementation and examination. 2.1.1/ 42 companies joined PPP, including WBL scheme and are involved in the implementation process. 2.1.2/ 16 agri-professions represented by effective PPPs In total 16 legal and sub-legal acts have been developed and approved by MoESCS
Output 2.2. Public and private partners are strengthened to contribute to the provision of farmer based extension services including short term training, counselling services, management advice, entrepreneurial support and other services. 2.2.1/ 4 PPP monitoring system 2.2.2/ Yes/1 STT system established and functional 2.2.3/ 2,720 additional GFA members (three categories) 2.2.4/ Amount of GFA’s non-donor funded income increase - 221,000GEL 2.2.5/ Yet to be performed in 2021 according to the project workplan - GFA accountability and transparency mechanism – 1 Financial audit in place 2.2.6 / 2 internal partnerships for VET and extension institutions established. 2.2.7 / 10 Colleges (including their branches) and training institutions obtained accreditation according to new regulations
Output 2.3. A-VET Teachers and Extension Officers have the capacity to deliver relevant, quality A-VET and extension services. 2.3.1. 3 in-service teachers and EO development activities. 8 subjects-based trainings developed and implemented for VET teachers as part of the Integrated 4th level programs implementation: (11 in total) 2.3.2/ 54 extension officers and trainers from 47 municipalities of the country trained through the In-Service Training Program. 299 VET teachers trained in Integrated 4th level programs implementation by NCEQE 2.3.3/ 23 A-VET institutions (10 already received and 13 are in process of acquiring authorization). 2.3.4 Under the Regional Activities 4 partner colleges are involved in short-term training programmes implementation together with Regional and Municipal ICCs
Output 3.1 (Self-) employment relevant measures including WBL are an integral part of A-VET provision 3.1.1/ 9 modules with e-learning system is place 3.1.2/ 10 integrated Entrepreneurship module 3.1.3/ 8 WBL authorized programs represented by effective PPPs (in total 11 WBL authorized programs are in place;
Output 3.2 High quality extension services and short-term trainings are offered to male and female farmers 3.2.1/ 16,200 farmers have been consulted in total (5,000 in 2019, 6,000 in 2020 and 5200 in 2021) and got information about the new technologies, information tools. practical recommendations. 3.2.2/ 5318 farmers accessing RDA digital platform /year (28618 in total)
Output 3.3 3.3.1; 1,500 students graduated A-VET studies including (300 short-term courses) in 2019 -2021 (45% women). 3.3.2 / 17 new WBL students joined program in 2021 (in total 2019-2020 71). 3.3.3/ 5 students and 10 teachers have participated in international exchange program financed by the College Support Fund in 2020-2021 3.3.4/ Digital learning concept approved by the Government (in process) 3.3.5/ 30 new STT packages in use. 3.3.6/16 Agri professions offered by partner VET colleges
